latest news.summary: Russian internet providers have begun to develop their own solutions to bypass YouTube's slowdown, allowing their customers to use the platform normally. According to 'Kommerstant', this is done by implementing special software, which is considered lawful by lawyers. The providers believe they are unlikely to be held accountable, as there is no official ban on YouTube in Russia. The government has not provided explanations for the slowdown. The director of 'Komfortel', Dmitry Petrov, thinks that operators are looking for ways to attract new subscribers before the active season by using bypassing means. Major providers 'Megafon', 'MTS', 'Vimpelcom', and 'Rostelecom' declined to comment on the information. 'Kommerstant' has sent a request to Roskomnadzor, but has not received a response yet.
latest news.title: Российские провайдеры начали сами обходить замедление YouTube — Лайфхакер

latest news.eng_title: Russian Operators Bypass YouTube Block, Citing 'No Additional Tools' Needed
latest news.summary: Russian telecommunications operators have implemented solutions to bypass the YouTube block in Russia, allowing users to access the platform without additional tools. According to a source in the industry, over 50 operators across the country have taken this initiative. One provider stated that user traffic is being redirected from Russian Google servers to European ones. This move comes after users began to cancel their contracts with providers, mistakenly blaming them for the issues with YouTube access. At least 135 Russian operators have seen a decline in customers. Experts believe that operators will not face punishment for this move, as Roskomnadzor has not announced any plans to slow down the service or add it to the list of banned social media platforms. Russian users have been experiencing issues with YouTube since August, with videos loading slowly or not loading at all without VPN services. In July, Rostelecom warned that YouTube may start to malfunction due to the wear and tear of Google servers in Russia. Google denied any involvement in the issues. In July, a State Duma deputy from United Russia, Alexander Khinstein, predicted a 70% slowdown of YouTube due to its 'anti-Russian policy'. He stated that this measure would initially affect only desktop versions. Meduza learned from a source in the telecommunications market that Russian authorities have decided to slow down YouTube to 128 kbps. After Russia's invasion of Ukraine, YouTube blocked many pro-Kremlin channels. On the other hand, opposition media continue to operate on the platform. Between May and June 2024, YouTube blocked around 3600 channels with Russian propaganda, which is believed to be the reason for the service's restrictions in Russia.
latest news.title: Операторы самовольно позволяют обходить блокировку ютьюба в РФ

latest news.eng_title: Russian ISPs Try to Bypass YouTube's Slowdowns
latest news.summary: Some Russian internet service providers (ISPs) are attempting to bypass YouTube's slowdowns, according to a report by 'Kommerstant' on August 28. Although there is no official statement from Roskomnadzor about the slowdown, the service has not been officially blocked in Russia and is not listed in the register of banned sites. This gives ISPs the grounds to take such measures, which are considered lawful by lawyers. According to the report, there are dozens of cases of ISPs implementing workarounds to bypass the block. In the Northwestern Federal District, journalists found messages from ISPs about YouTube working on their networks without 'additional tools' for users, as well as redirecting user traffic from Russian Google servers to European ones. 'Some operators are looking for ways to attract new subscribers before the active season by using means of bypassing, while counting on minimal responsibility, as there is no official ban on YouTube,' said Dmitry Petrov, general director of the 'Komfortel' operator. More than 135 regional ISPs have asked the Ministry of Digital Development and Roskomnadzor for clarification on what is happening with YouTube. According to 'Kommerstant', the problems may be caused by traffic slowdown due to the work of technical means of counteracting threats by Roskomnadzor. As a reminder, on August 1, users began to notice disruptions in YouTube's work, and on August 8, it stopped opening for some users. Before that, State Duma deputy Alexander Khinstein announced the slowdown of YouTube, explaining that it was a forced step 'against the administration of a foreign resource.' Google stated that the complexities in the service's work on Russian territory are not the result of technical failures.
latest news.title: «Ъ»: некоторые операторы связи пробуют самостоятельно ускорить YouTube

latest news.eng_title: Russian ISPs Find Ways to Bypass YouTube's Slowdown
latest news.summary: Russian internet service providers (ISPs) have started using solutions to bypass YouTube's slowdown, citing that the service is not officially banned in Russia. According to sources, some ISPs have implemented measures to redirect traffic from Russian Google servers to European ones, allowing users to access YouTube without additional tools. Dmitry Petrov, CEO of 'Komfortel', stated that some companies are trying to attract new subscribers by using means to bypass YouTube's slowdown, claiming that they will not be held responsible since YouTube is not officially banned in Russia. Oleg Grishchenko, president of the 'Rostelecom' association, also believes that there are no legal issues with these actions. However, Ekatrina Abashina, an attorney from the First Digital Collegium, warned that ISPs may face administrative penalties for manipulating traffic. The slowdown of YouTube in Russia began in August, with users reporting difficulties in accessing video content. Alexander Khinstein, head of the Duma committee on information policy, attributed the issue to Google's 'anti-Russian policy', but later explained that it was due to problems with data storage in Russian data centers. 'Rostelecom' also linked the issue to problems with Google's equipment, which had not been updated since the start of the war in Ukraine. Google denied any technical issues or actions on their part. According to Mediascope, Russian users spent an average of 111 minutes per day on YouTube from May to July, but this time decreased to 96 minutes in the second half of August, with users spending around 91-92 minutes per day on the service.
latest news.title: «Ъ» узнал о попытках операторов справиться с замедлением YouTube

latest news.summary: Deputy Secretary of the Security Council Dmitry Medvedev stated that YouTube's actions are unacceptable, as the platform is completely removing Russian journalists, bloggers, and companies from its platform, while promoting resources of Russia's opponents and enemies. 'They are completely removing our resources, while promoting resources of our opponents and enemies, quite frankly. That's not right. We've told them repeatedly: You're supposed to maintain some balance. But no,' Medvedev said. Medvedev noted that there is nothing good in this situation. Blocking or slowing down YouTube in Russia does not benefit anyone, but Moscow cannot ignore the platform's overtly anti-Russian actions.
latest news.title: Медведев: Ограничения YouTube - это плохо, но действия платформы недопустимы

latest news.eng_title: Medvedev Criticizes YouTube's Hostile Actions Towards Russia
latest news.summary: Russian Deputy Security Council Chairman Dmitry Medvedev stated that YouTube's actions are 'openly hostile' towards Russia, as they remove Russian resources and promote the country's enemies. According to Medvedev, YouTube has been conducting a hostile policy and refusing to comply with Russia's requests to balance opinions. He added that this behavior is the reason for the imposed restrictions. As reported by ИА Регнум, YouTube stopped working on computers for most Russian residents on August 8. The website is not loading regardless of the internet provider, and some users are receiving error messages, while others are experiencing 'infinite' loading. On July 26, Roskomnadzor stated that numerous violations of Russian law and disrespect towards Russia and its citizens are the grounds for taking measures against YouTube. The State Duma also warned that YouTube's speed in Russia will slow down to 70% in the near future due to Russian data centers ceasing cooperation with Google. Meanwhile, two Russian women who were banned from leaving Turkey after an incident at Antalya airport have been allowed to return to Russia. According to the Russian Consulate General in Antalya, the ban was lifted due to humanitarian circumstances, and the women safely returned to Russia on August 27. The Consulate General also advised Russian citizens to plan their trips responsibly and respect the laws and norms of the country they are visiting.
latest news.title: Медведев заявил, что действия YouTube носят откровенно враждебный характер Москва, 27 августа, 2024, 18:51 — ИА Регнум. Заместитель председателя Совета безопасности РФ Дмитрий Медведев заявил, что американский видеохостинг YouTube ведёт себя некрасиво, зачищая российские ресурсы и продвигая врагов страны. germany_photography YouTube «Они полностью зачищают наши ресурсы, а ресурсы наших оппонентов и наших врагов — скажем прямо — продвигают. Ну, это неправильно», — сказал Медведев. По его словам, ограничения введены из-за того, что сервис проводит враждебную политику, а также отказывается выполнять просьбы России соблюдать баланс мнений. Медведев добавил, что таким образом YouTube демонстрирует некрасивое поведение, которое стало причиной соответствующих ограничений. Как сообщало ИА Регнум, 8 августа YouTube перестал работать на компьютерах у большей части жителей России. Его сайт не загружается вне зависимости от провайдера домашнего интернета, у некоторых пользователей он выдает ошибку, а ещё у части показывает «бесконечную» загрузку. 26 июля Роскомнадзор заявил, что многочисленные нарушения российского законодательства, а также неуважение к России и её гражданам являются основанием для принятия мер в отношении YouTube. В этот же день в Госдуме предупредили, что YouTube в России в скором времени замедлится до 70%. Причиной этого станет то, что российские дата-центры, которые сотрудничают с платформой Google (владельцем видеохостинга), намерены в ближайшие дни прекратить работу с компанией по «серым» схемам. Заместитель директора департамента информации и печати МИД РФ Андрей Настасьин заявил, что YouTube не является нейтральной интернет-платформой, ориентирующейся на интересы своей аудитории, а отрабатывает политические установки властей США. Дипломат напомнил, что администрация видеохостинга продолжает игнорировать законные требования Роскомнадзора об удалении материалов экстремистского характера. Дмитрий Медведев YouTube

latest news.eng_title: Medvedev: Russia Tried to Prevent YouTube Slowdown Due to Hostile Character
latest news.summary: Russian authorities attempted to negotiate with YouTube representatives to prevent the service's slowdown, but the video hosting platform had a hostile attitude, leaving them with no other options. According to Deputy Chairman of the Russian Security Council Dmitry Medvedev, 'They completely clean our resources, while resources of our opponents and enemies - to put it bluntly - are promoted. Well, that's not right. We've told them many times: 'You're supposed to maintain some balance'. But no', he said during a meeting with candidates from his party 'United Russia' who are participating in the Special Military Operation. Medvedev acknowledged that it's not good when some sources of information are missing, but if a service has a hostile character, it's a different story. He stated that this is the reason for the slowdown of the video service.
latest news.title: «Неоднократно говорили»: Медведев заявил, что Россия пыталась предотвратить замедление YouTube

latest news.eng_title: Medvedev Calls YouTube Restriction 'Not Very Good' but Necessary
latest news.summary: Russian Deputy Security Council Chairman Dmitry Medvedev stated that the YouTube restriction in Russia is due to the platform's hostile policy towards the country. According to Medvedev, YouTube's management 'behaves very badly' by removing Russian resources and promoting those of the country's opponents. He emphasized that the authorities asked the platform to maintain a balance, but this was not done. Medvedev acknowledged that limiting the choice of information sources 'is not very good', but continuing to allow 'hostile resources' is impossible. He said, 'From here, state decisions are made to take restrictive measures if our wishes are not fulfilled.' A recent Mediascope study found that the average time Russians spend on YouTube daily has decreased from 52 to 38 minutes since the end of July.
latest news.title: Медведев назвал «не очень хорошим», но необходимым ограничение YouTube

latest news.eng_title: Medvedev Accuses YouTube of Unpleasant Behavior
latest news.summary: Russian Security Council Deputy Chairman Dmitry Medvedev has criticized YouTube for its 'unpleasant behavior', stating that the platform is promoting enemies of Russia and removing Russian resources. Medvedev said, 'There is nothing good in the slowdown of YouTube.' He also considered it unacceptable for the platform to be hostile towards Russia. This comes after Russian Foreign Ministry official Maria Zakharova commented on the restrictions, stating that there are 'substantial grounds' for their implementation. Earlier, State Duma Committee Chairman Alexander Khinstein announced that YouTube would be slowed down in Russia, with video loading speeds reduced to 70%. He stated that this decision would target the platform's administration for violating Russian law.
latest news.title: Медведев обвинил YouTube в некрасивом поведении

news knowledge.eng_title: Vladimir Putin restricts social media sites and YouTube
news knowledge.summary: The Russian government has been restricting access to social media platforms, including YouTube, Facebook, and Instagram, by slowing down or blocking them. Experts warn that a complete nationwide ban on YouTube is imminent. Since the restrictions were introduced, the user base of foreign social networks in Russia has declined significantly, with Instagram's daily user count decreasing from 38.4 million in February 2022 to 6.8 million in February 2024. IT specialist Mikhail Klimarev stated, 'Blocking YouTube would be a clear act of censorship.' Users like Christina, 25, have adapted to the restricted digital landscape by using VPNs, which are also being targeted by the government. Klimarev explained, 'In October 2023, they issued a law banning the promotion of methods to bypass blockages and the blocking of resources describing these methods.' The situation with YouTube remains uncertain, but popular shows have already shifted to the alternative platform VKontakte, which is widely believed to be under government influence and control. Klimarev stated, 'I think we're just one step away from a complete shutdown.'
news knowledge.title: Vladimir Putin restricts social media sites and YouTube

news knowledge.eng_title: Russia Slows Down YouTube, Threatening Right to Information
news knowledge.summary: The Russian government has slowed down YouTube's video playback speed in Russia, making it difficult to access the platform. The 'Reporters Without Borders' (RSF) organization has condemned this move, stating that it threatens the right to information. According to RSF, 'The Kremlin is on its way to achieving its dirty goal - locking Russian citizens in an information prison where only propaganda can freely circulate.' The organization has called for the Russian government to restore normal video playback speed on the platform. Users in occupied Ukrainian regions, as well as in Moscow and St. Petersburg, have reported difficulties accessing YouTube due to the slowed-down video playback speed. The Russian government has been gradually blocking YouTube, reducing the video playback speed to 128 kbps, which is significantly lower than the required level for optimal playback. This move is being implemented using 'technical means of countering threats' (TMT), also known as 'black boxes,' which are being installed in telecommunications operators in Russia since 2020 and are controlled by Roskomnadzor, the Russian telecommunications regulator. YouTube has been under scrutiny in Russia for several months, with Roskomnadzor accusing it of spreading disinformation about the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The Russian government has warned that it will take direct action against the platform. According to a source close to the Russian administration, YouTube may be completely blocked by the fall, with the service's performance gradually deteriorating this summer. Independent media and journalists, forced to live in exile, have developed their own video formats on YouTube to circumvent the censorship imposed by the Kremlin, which is tightening its control over the internet. The success of YouTube is evident in the data from a report by The Fix and JX Fund, a journalism support fund created by RSF, which shows that in September 2023, videos from independent journalists and media reached 165 million views on the platform. One of the reasons for this popularity is that YouTube, unlike Facebook and Instagram, has not been banned by the Russian authorities. A protest rally planned by users in Moscow on August 17 to protest the slowdown of YouTube was banned by the authorities. Russia ranks 162nd out of 180 countries in the World Press Freedom Index by RSF for 2024.
news knowledge.title: RSF засудили уповільнення роботи ютуб у Росії, що ставить під загрозу право на інформацію

news knowledge.eng_title: Russia Does Not Plan to Block YouTube, But Will Slow Down Its Speed
news knowledge.summary: Russian authorities have stated that they do not plan to block YouTube, but instead will slow down its speed. According to Deputy Anton Gorelkin, the Russian government does not want to take measures that would harm citizens. He stated, 'Such a scenario is not being considered, because there is an important principle - retaliatory measures should not harm our citizens.' Gorelkin also emphasized that Google must return to Russia officially, pay fines, reopen its representation, and comply with local legislation in the Russian segment. The speed of YouTube may decrease to 40% and then to 70% due to the lack of support for caching servers in Russian networks, according to the Roskomnadzor. This measure is a result of 'multiple violations' of Russian legislation by YouTube. The Russian court has already fined Google over 25 billion rubles in the last three years, but this measure has not helped. YouTube, owned by American Google, stopped monetizing content for Russian users in March 2022. In 2022, an arbitration court in Moscow arrested the assets and property of the Russian subsidiary of Google for 1.5 billion rubles. In October 2023, the court recognized OOO 'Google' as bankrupt. The competitive manager of OOO 'Google' Valery Talyarovsky reported that the amount of claims from creditors, included in the register, at that time was 54 billion rubles. Roskomnadzor sent a requirement to the director of Google Sundar Pichai to unblock over 200 YouTube accounts of Russian media, authorities, and public figures in mid-July. Since 2020, YouTube has restricted 207 Russian resources, with 83 of them in 2024, according to the agency.
news knowledge.title: В Госдуме заявили об отсутствии планов принудительной блокировки YouTube в России

news knowledge.eng_title: Russia May Ban Google, Android, and iOS, Says Liberal Democratic Party Member
news knowledge.summary: Russian Liberal Democratic Party member Alexey Didenko stated that Google, Android, and iOS may soon be banned in Russia. Didenko does not see this as a tragic situation, citing the example of Netflix, which suspended its operations in Russia in March 2022. Last week, State Duma Committee on Information Policy, Information Technologies and Communications Chairman Alexander Khinshtein announced that YouTube would be slowed down in Russia due to the platform's inability to pay the service fees for Russian data centers. Google later commented on the situation, stating that it would continue to operate in Russia, but did not provide further details.
news knowledge.title: Komite Başkanı Açıkladı: Rusya'da Google, Android ve iOS Yasaklanabilir

news knowledge.eng_title: Russia Considers Blocking YouTube and Replacing it with VK
news knowledge.summary: The Russian authorities are considering blocking YouTube and replacing it with VK, a social media platform controlled by the government. This move is seen as part of a broader effort to control the internet and create a culture of self-censorship in Russia. The Russian Federal Censorship Agency, Roskomnadzor, has accused YouTube of numerous violations of Russian law and disrespect towards Russia and its citizens. Experts believe that this is a step towards controlling the online activities of Russians and creating a culture of self-censorship. The head of the State Duma's Committee on Information Policy, Alexander Khinstein, has stated that YouTube will be loaded 40% slower in the coming days due to Russian data centers ceasing cooperation with Google. Meanwhile, the Russian telecommunications giant Rostelecom has attributed the slow loading of YouTube to a lack of Russian servers. The opposition publication Verstka has reported that Russia aims to replace YouTube with VK by loading all Russian-language videos from YouTube to VK by autumn 2024. This move is seen as a step towards creating a controlled online environment. The Russian government has also expanded its legislation to cover not only everyday life but also the internet, with the aim of protecting government officials and military personnel from 'discreditation'. The Kremlin has also emphasized the importance of creating a culture of censorship, including the use of only approved software and self-censorship of opposition or other content that is not favorable to the government's goals.
news knowledge.title: Закроют YouTube и заменят на VK: в ISW предположили дальнейшие действия Кремля в отношении видеохостинга

news knowledge.eng_title: Protest in Moscow against YouTube blocking of Russian channels
news knowledge.summary: Hundreds of people, including Russian singer Shaman, gathered in front of the US embassy in Moscow on Friday to protest the blocking of some Russian channels on YouTube, according to RIA Novosti news agency. Shaman was present at the gathering, which was held after he announced earlier on Friday that he wanted to organize a march against what he considered an 'unlawful' blocking of some Russian channels on YouTube. He said, 'No one will ban our songs.' The Russian government has banned most gatherings in the capital, except for those organized by the Kremlin to criticize the West. In Russia, people who participate in banned gatherings face severe penalties. Before weeks, the European Commission announced that Shaman had been put under sanctions due to his support for Russia's military attack on Ukraine, which began in February 2022. His channel was blocked on YouTube in early July. On Tuesday, Russia requested that Google lift the ban on over 200 Russian channels on YouTube, citing 'propaganda' by the Kremlin. The Russian government has also tightened its control over the internet since the start of its attack on Ukraine, blocking several websites where critics of the Kremlin can express themselves freely, such as Facebook and Instagram. YouTube has not been completely blocked, but rumors about the possibility of blocking spread regularly, especially since the Federal Communications Agency 'Roskomnadzor' accused Google and YouTube of 'terrorist activities' in March 2022.
news knowledge.title: تظاهرة أمام السفارة الأميركية في موسكو إثر حجب قنوات عبر "يوتيوب"

news knowledge.eng_title: Kremlin denies claim of imminent YouTube ban
news knowledge.summary: The Kremlin has denied claims that YouTube will be banned in Russia, citing technical issues related to Google's outdated servers in the country. The Russian authorities have no plans to restrict access to YouTube, according to Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov. Peskov explained that the slowdowns on YouTube are caused by technical issues and not by any decision made by the Russian government. He also stated that Russian companies have probably already tried to reach out to YouTube to remedy the issue. The deputy head of the State Duma Committee on Information Policy, Anton Gorelkin, also confirmed that the issues with the speed of service of YouTube in Russia are not occurring due to any decision made by the country's regulator.
news knowledge.title: Kremlin denies claim of imminent YouTube ban

news knowledge.eng_title: YouTube to be blocked in Russia by September 2024
news knowledge.summary: According to gazeta.ru, citing a source close to the presidential administration, YouTube will be fully blocked in Russia by September 2024. The same information was confirmed by a source in a company that provides information to law enforcement agencies. The source described a gradual degradation of YouTube services in July-August, with some regions experiencing slower or malfunctioning services. In September, the full blockage of the platform is expected to begin. Another source also received information about the shutdown of the service in the fall. Previously, the press secretary of the Russian president, Dmitry Peskov, stated that there are no plans to block YouTube.
news knowledge.title: Gazeta.ru: YouTube в России заблокируют уже осенью

news knowledge.eng_title: YouTube Bans Over 80 Russian Channels, Faces Fines and Criticism from Russian Authorities
news knowledge.summary: YouTube has banned over 80 Russian channels since the beginning of the year, according to the Russian Federal Service for Supervision in the Sphere of Mass Communications, Information Technology and Mass Media (Roskomnadsor). The Russian authorities have accused YouTube of censorship, stating that the platform has restricted access to 83 Russian resources since January 2024. Additionally, YouTube has failed to remove or block prohibited content in Russia, with over 61,300 illegal contents remaining online. Roskomnadsor has threatened YouTube with fines of up to 10% of the company's annual revenue and a minimum fine of 4 million rubles (approximately 42,000 euros) for repeated violations. The agency has also criticized YouTube for not deleting or blocking prohibited content within 24 hours of being notified, as required by Russian law.
news knowledge.title: YouTube sperrt allein seit Jahresbeginn weitere 80 mit Russland verbundene Kanäle

news knowledge.summary: According to Roskomnadzor, YouTube blocked 83 Russian channels in 2024. Since 2020, the video hosting platform has restricted access to over 200 channels from Russia. Additionally, YouTube has not removed over 61,300 prohibited content materials on its platform, including misinformation about the special military operation in Ukraine or LGBTQ+ propaganda, which is recognized as extremist and banned in Russia. The restrictions also affected channels of Russian musicians such as Oleg Gazmanov, Julia Chicherina, Grigory Leps, and SHAMAN (real name Yaroslav Dronov), as well as actor and blogger Vyacheslav Manucharov.
news knowledge.title: Названо число заблокированных на YouTube российских каналов
